_header: Sing I would but alas decedunt prospera grata
Subjects: evils of the times; satires; estates literature; manners; clothing, against extremes of
_description: Macaronic verses lamenting the Evils of the Age, temp. Richard II — 140 lines in quatrains, alternately English and Latin lines. For the last two lines and Latin couplet occurring separately see 2466

BodRawC86.Transcription:
Synge I wold but alas discedant prospera grataInglond sum tyme
                    was recuorum gemma parataOf manhode the floure vbi quondam
                        fuerunt hominesBut now is gome þat owre traduntur talia
                        sompnis

BLHar536.First Lines: Syng I wolde but alas descedunt prospera grataIn ynglonde sumtyme was regnorum gemma vocata…
BLHar536.Last Lines: …Oure kyng & oure lord seruet regat & tenaturGod that with his honde celum terram moderaturIn age as hee growith sua crescat gratia fructuFul litle hee knowith quanto dolet Anglia luctu
BLHar536.Note:
The first line is not repeated on f. 125 as given in Boffey  and  Edwards (2005)
XJulia Boffey,   and  A. S. G. Edwards.  
             A New Index of Middle English Verse.
         London: The British Library, 2005; MS has inly 61 folios; Here the last two lines and the Latin couplet that follows are added by a later hand, so they may have circulated as a separate piece, as in 2466.
BLHar536.Editions:
Fairholt,  Frederick William. 
             “Satirical Songs and Poems on Costume.” 
             Percy Society
         27. London: Richards, 1849: 44-8.

BLHar941.First Lines: Syng I wold butt alas decedunt prospera grataynglond sum tyme was regnorum gemma perata…
BLHar941.Last Lines: …In age as he grows sua crescat gratia fructuffull lytell he knowes quanto dolet anglia luctu
BLHar941.Note: Two Latin couplets follow, “hic quicumque legat…” and “O rex si rex es….”
BLHar941.Attributed Title: Of monhod þe flowre ibi quondam floruit omnibus (f. 21v)
BLHar941.Facsimiles:
Digital Facsimile of British Library Harley MS 941.
         https://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?index=0&ref=Harley_MS_941.

TCD516.First Lines:
Syngyn y wolde but alasdiscendunt procedunt prospera
                    grataEnglond sum tyme wasRegnorum gemma
                    vocata…
TCD516.Last Lines:
…In age as he growyt sua gestat gratia fructufful
                    welle þat he knowequantum sit anglia luctuO rex si rex
                        es rege tevel eris sine re rexNomen habes sine reubi to recte
                        que regas rex
TCD516.Attributed Title:
Explicit Auctore scriptum / Nunc finem feci dai mihi quod merui (f.
                    108)
TCD516.Editions:
Wright,  Thomas,
                        ed.  
             Political Poems and Songs relating to English History, composed during
                the period From the Accession of Edward III to that of Richard III.
             2 vols. 
             Rolls Series
         14 (1859, 1861); repr. Kraus, 1965: 70-8.
